org.javaconfig.api

Interface Scope


  • public interface Scope
    A configuration scope identifies a subset of configuration available. A scope is identified by a unique name and provides accessor to determine if a scope is availale in a certain runtime context.

    By default the following scopes are defined, in order of priority:

    • domain_defaults (VM)
    • domain entries (VM)
    • domain_test entries (VM)
    • application_defaults (ear)
    • application entries (ear)
    • application_test entries (ear)
    • web_defaults (war)
    • web entries (war)
    • web_test entries (war)

    Scopes allow to independently model the levels of overrides required by the an application, or application landscape. Additional scopes can be added that may override or extend the existing flavors.
    With ConfigurationQuery completely independent configurations can be created, that define different scope ordering as required.

    Author:
    Anatole Tresch

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.lang.String getName()
      Returns the unique name of a scope.
      boolean isActive()
      Accessor called to determine if a scope is available within the current context.
      boolean isContextual()
      Method allows to determine if a scope is contextual.

    • Method Detail

      • getName

        java.lang.String getName()
        Returns the unique name of a scope.
        Returns:
        The scope's name, never null.

      • isActive

        boolean isActive()
        Accessor called to determine if a scope is available within the current context.
        Returns:
        true, if the scope is available in the current context.

      • isContextual

        boolean isContextual()
        Method allows to determine if a scope is contextual. Configuration of contextual scopes are accessed whenever they are needed.
        Returns:
        true, if this scope is contextual.
